definition: a wheel with a row of teeth around the edge that connect with the holes of a bicycle chain or with holes in a film, etc. in order to turn it
one of the teeth on such a wheel
the action of pulling something along a surface; the power that is used for doing this
a way of treating a broken bone in your body that involves using special equipment to pull the bone gradually back into its correct place
the force that stops something, for example the wheels of a vehicle, from sliding on the ground
the extent to which an idea, a product, etc. becomes popular or gains support
one of the thin bars or long, straight pieces of metal that connect the centre of a wheel to its outer edge, for example on a bicycle
to prevent somebody from putting their plans into operation
a small shop that sells fashionable clothes or expensive gifts
a list of goods that have been sold, work that has been done, etc., showing what you must pay
the part of the ovary of a plant containing the female cell, which becomes the seed when it is fertilized
a part of a flower, like a leaf, that lies under and supports the petals (= the thin coloured parts that make up the head of the flower). Each flower has a ring of sepals called a calyx.
the ring of small green leaves (called sepals) that protect a flower before it opens
a thin wire in a light bulb that produces light when electricity is passed through it
a long thin piece of something that looks like a thread
that connects things
the jawbone
the upper or lower part of a bird’s beak
either of the two parts that are at the front and on either side of an insect’s mouth, used especially for biting and crushing food
the jaw
a small cabin with walls and a roof on a ship where the person controlling the direction in which the ship moves stands at the wheel
a person's area of expert knowledge or experience
if a pitch (= throw of the ball) is in your wheelhouse, it is in the area where it is easiest to hit
a long narrow bar that you can hold onto for support, for example when you are going up or down stairs
a wooden or metal bar placed around something as a barrier or to provide support
a bar fixed to the wall for hanging things on
each of the two metal bars that form the track that trains run on
railways as a means of transport
to become successful again after a period of failure, or to begin functioning normally again
to start behaving in a way that is strange or unacceptable, for example drinking a lot or taking drugs
to lose control and stop functioning correctly
to leave the track suddenly
a small wooden or metal bar fastened to something, on which ropes may be fastened by winding
a piece of rubber on the bottom of a shoe, etc. to stop it from slipping
shoes with cleats, often worn for playing sports
a thick cylinder that winds up a rope, used for lifting heavy objects such as an anchor on a ship
the main, bottom part of a ship, that goes in the water
a town or city with a harbour, especially one where ships load and unload goods
a place where ships load and unload goods or shelter from storms
a strong sweet wine, usually dark red, that is made in Portugal. It is usually drunk at the end of a meal.
a glass of port
the side of a ship or aircraft that is on the left when you are facing forward
a place on a computer where you can attach another piece of equipment, often using a cable
if you are in great trouble, you take any help that is offered
the side of a ship or an aircraft that is on the right when you are facing forward
the upper edge of the side of a boat or small ship
a sea creature with a body like jelly and long thin parts called tentacles that can give a sharp sting (= a painful wound on the skin)
the female organs of a flower, which receive the pollen and produce seeds
the part of a plant in which seeds are produced
